data.text:
Home

Life

Diaries

1960s

1964

1964

January 1 - December 31, 1964

(Box 5/Folder 7)

January 1, 1964

I slept till eight. Then I took down my tree and other decorations and cleaned up the mess & put away my cards. It was bright and clear except for one brief spell of fog. Got fairly warm in the afternoon. The students are visiting the Branens and the Huffers.

January 2, 1964

I drove to Enid to see Mrs. Hawkins, found her still too complaining not like her long, patient suffering. In the evening the Gradwohl family called, but soon had to leave because the children were too tired and sleepy

January 3, 1964

Bright day, wind from north, I took some Kennedy material down to the O’Neill’s and enjoyed seeing them so much I spent the evening. It is a great pleasure to talk with those two bright young people. Ramona got some cake and tea and we talked some more.

January 4, 1964

Cold and bright in the morning but warmed up. I drove over to Stillwater, had dinner with the Fischers and spent the afternoon Started home just after sunset and had the glory of this strange red sky all the way home.

January 5, 1964

I had a fine S.S. class, then church (communion service). In the evening had dinner basket dinner at the church, and congregational meeting afterwards. Adopted 1964 budget, elected some officers, listened to some reports, and unanimously passed declaration of open membership without regard to race, class, or ethnic origins.

January 6, 1964

Rev. John Gradwohl called briefly about a news item. Also Pat O’Neill dropped by. I took a bowl of “ruby red” jello salad to Mabel Bryson. Mabel has flu and looks very thin and ill.

January 7, 1964

Olga Schaefer called saying she had been to see Mabel. Found her much better, but weak.

January 8, 1964

Women’s Guild meeting at church. Good program by Elsie Seefeldt.

January 9, 1964

Turned two pages. Olga called saying she had been to see Mabel – found her much better. Attended a very pleasant reception at Zion church in O.C. for the new conference minister & his wife, Rev, & Mrs. Craig. I rode down with Paul & Horene Schler – enjoyed the visit with them.

January 10, 1964

Nothing in particular happened. We have been having pleasant weather ever since Christmas. This evening I found Pearl Burchardt was about helpless with a sudden attack of arthritis in her hip. I took care of her and put her to bed.

January 11, 1964

Pearl was not better this morning. I did somethings for her and then called Edith Holloway from Stillwater. Nora Frank brought her a good dinner. Edith came shortly after noon and called the doctor. Pearl is not ill, only the arthritis pain.

January 12, 1964

It turned very cold during the night – some snow fell, and more this morning, high wind. A fair congregation at church. I taught my class. Edith had to return to Stillwater in the evening. I took got Pearl’s supper, spent the evening with her, and settled her for the night. I suppose the temperature is about 7ᵒ.

January 13, 1964

Clear day, warmed up gradually. I got up at six and got my own breakfast, then took care of Pearl, also got her dinner and supper. Elmer came this evening with Jerry to stay overnight. She is better. I took time off for a conference with Ramona and one with Mabel.

January 14, 1964

Elmer and Jerry got Pearl’s breakfast. I had a meeting in my house of the international hospitality committee 9 to 10, made plans for between semesters Jan. 24. In the afternoon attended club at Almeda Grassman’s. Fine program by Ramona. I got Pearl’s dinner and supper. Elmer is staying tonight.

January 15, 1964

Edith Holloway spent the afternoon with her mother, worked like a whirlwind washing, cleaning house, etc. She wanted to take her mother home with her but Pearl didn’t want to go. She is O.K. here – not sick only very lame. I can cook her meals, all the neighbors come in and do for her. Elmer and Jerry with her at night. She is slowly improving Lovely weather.

January 16, 1964

I am still cooking two of Pearl’s meals. Elmer and Jerry stay overnight with her and cook her breakfast. She does not improve much, but the doctor came today and said she was doing as well as could be expected.

January 17, 1964

Pearl is really better today. She dressed and sat in the living room. Elmer brought Jerry to take care of her over the week end. He called me and said he would get her supper. He is such a good child – will stay with her till he has to go back to school Monday

January 18, 1964

Spent the day Zion Church in O.C. – an association S. S. Teachers of the Okla. Assn. of the church preparing the next semester’s course. I was greatly interested in the study of the pictures – new and very modern but meaningful. The Brysons and Evadean and I went down besides the pastor & family. Pearl not any better this evening

January 19, 1964

Nice warm day. I even wore my spring suit to church. I had a fine S.S. class. Good crowd at church – nearly all the seats full. Edith Holloway took her mother to Stillwater. She has not improved very much the past week.

January 20, 1964

Drove to Enid to see Mrs. Hawkins – spent most of the time with her writing letters. She seems more like herself but still hates the nurse, lovely warm day.

January 21, 1964

Spent the forenoon at a meeting of the library board. With Winnie Branen as librarian we are really getting things done.

January 22, 1964

Called Mrs. Levin and she tells me we shall have twelve students to visit us Friday. Lovely day.

January 23, 1964

Spent much time at the school arranging visits to various classes for the foreign students who are coming tomorrow. So lovely and warm I turned my furnace off in the afternoon.

January 24, 1964

Colder, with disagreeable wind. Three of us took cars to Stillwater, brought back eleven foreign students to visit in homes and at school. It seemed a very happy occasion for our people and them. One couple from India, the rest men.

January 25, 1964

Nice day, a little crisp in the morning but warmed up.

January 26, 1964

I had a wonderful S.S. class today. The young people had charge of the church service – a beautiful service – except that the pastor preached the sermon, good sermon. Nelle Thomas came to visit me this P.M. Later I called on Vernon Fickin, who is ill. Lovely day.

January 27, 1964

[No entry]

January 28, 1964

Attended club at Ramona O’Neill’s – good meeting, but I drew an assignment to write the year’s history for federation files.

January 29, 1964

Worked on a club history I must get mailed tomorrow. In the evening Pat and Ramona O’Neill and young, charming father Helenh Hellinghausen came and I showed my Russian pictures. Then we talked as usual about politics – upon which we are all agreed. Sprinkling this evening.

January 30, 1964

Dark rainy day – not much moisture I’m afraid but better than none. I finished and mailed my club history. Worked so hard I didn’t even remember it was my birthday – or at least scarcely thought of it.

January 31, 1964

Drove to Stillwater and am staying with Idress Cash. We saw Saroyan’s “The Cave Dwellers” by the university theater guild. Very well done. Cloudy this morning, clear this afternoon, warm all day. My plumbing clogged just before I left. Oh yes, I visited Cherrie Garrett.

February 1, 1964

Spent morning talking with Idress. Got home about noon. Woodrow Winburn opened up my plumbing but I should get Joe to go under the house. Weather so lovely one can hardly believe it. I baked cookies for a reception at the church tomorrow.

February 2, 1964

Mean windy day. I had a fine S.S. class and attended church (better sermon than usual). In afternoon my young friend Edward Oliver and his parents and aunt called. Pearl Burchardt came home, able to walk O. K. but still some pain in leg. In the evening pastor was installed – very fine sermon by Rev. Geo. Ellerbrake of O.C. Reception afterwards.

February 3, 1964

Some sprinkling in morning but cleared off. Joe Miser came but decided it was best to leave my plumbing as it is since the drain is open now.

February 4, 1964

Rained all day – quiet drizzle, but with last week’s rain it was more than an inch, and none ran off. Nice and warm.

February 5, 1964

Cleared off but seems to be turning cold this evening. Clouds in the west that look like snow. I went to Guild, not many there on account of the mud. Good lesson by Mabel Bryson.

February 6, 1964

Clear and nice though rather cold this morning. In fact I used the tumbler at the automat instead of hanging up my wash in the high north wind. I called on the O’Neill’s but didn’t stay long because Ramona looked ill.

February 7, 1964

Nice day. Attended a meeting at the library to encourage the reading of books.

February 8, 196[4]

Nice day. I am working on a report I must give at club. Jim Edwards called briefly to ask about a writer named Cantonwine who wrote a book about the 46th Star in 1911. I never heard of him.

February 9, 1964

I had a rather small S.S. class, Heard a good sermon. (Rev. John is improving) Worked in the afternoon on a report for Club Tuesday. Would do it tomorrow but Lucille Barr and a man from Hennessey are coming. Warm day.

February 10, 196[4]

Worked on club program – life and work of Geo. Catlin. Lucille Barr, Mr. Dinkler and Mrs. Wickstrom came for some historical background to be used in a pageant for April 22.

February 11, 1964

Club at Margaret Perdue’s. Very small attendance, several sick. I had the program. In the evening went to lodge room to practice for initiation. I have not been attending lodge since the first half of last year.

February 12, 1964

I worked on the background of the pageant and got it but didn’t get much done. Miserable dark day, some rain once, feels as though it could snow. In the evening went to lenten [sic] service, used pictures, very interesting. I seem to have a cold coming on

February 13, 1964

Finished what I promised to do for the Hennessey people – mailed it to the company they have employed to put on the pageant. It was clear this morning – the threatened storm missed us. I am really feeling a cold coming.

February 14, 1964

Cold bothered me much during the night. Thought I would have to call Mabel in the morning and say I couldn’t take my part in World Day of Prayer. But coffee helped and I went on. Very fine service – at our church this time. Slept in afternoon. Feel much better this evening.

February 15, 1964

Rained last night but cleared up during the afternoon. I kept the library in this afternoon. My cold still making me about very uncomfortable.

February 16, 1964

Still ill with the cold. But I taught my S.S. class. (It isn’t flu or I wouldn’t have exposed people.) Didn’t stay for church. In the afternoon Hulda and Richard Weber celebrated their golden wedding – such a good 50 years! First a beautiful simple service in the church – then a reception in the basement.

February 17, 1964

Felt bad this morning but improved during the day. Virtually well this evening. It rained all afternoon – a slow drizzle. Not cold.

February 18, 1964

Clear, beautiful spring morning with clean sky and clean air – got a little windy in the afternoon. I am all over my cold but some hoarseness.

February 19, 1964

Started work on a report of the library improvement initiated by the Marshall Woman’s Club. We are entering it in a Community Improvement Contest.

February 20, 1964

More hard work on my report.

February 21, 1964

Taught my S.S. class (small crowd) and attended church. In the afternoon worked on my report. More hard work on my report.

February 22, 1964

More hard work on my report. Dianne Phelan and Cue boy married. I didn’t attend – wasn’t invited, not a special friend though I do like the family very much.

February 23, 1964

Taught my S. S. class (small attendance) and attended church. In the afternoon worked on my club report.

February 24, 1964

Worked hard on my report. Got it finished only proof-reading and writing some summaries. Tomorrow I must go to the City to a meeting of State Council of Churches committee on Christian social concern.

February 25, 1964

Dark day. I started to City – came back because afraid of snow or freezing rain. Worked on report some, attended Club in P.M. When I started home my windshield was completely iced over. Anita Shulty helped me, scraped a little hole so I could drive 3 blocks home. Glad I didn’t go to the City.

February 26, 1964

After yesterday’s entry went to Pat Oneills’ to watch Maria Tallchief dance on their new TV- impressed mainy[sic] with how bad TV is even with Maria Tallchief. Then we listened on radio to Cassius Clay win heavyweight boxing title over Liston. Upset. Clear today – storm over, still rather cold. Worked on report.

February 27, 1964

Ila Smith came this morning and did some last minute pasting, etc. We packaged the report and she mailed it. I spent rest of day catching up on writing, especially to Mary Shank, who has much to worry about. Drove to see Mrs. Hawkins in the afternoon. She is really gaining strength.

February 28, 1964

Spent the day catching up on letters neglected during writing of club report. Especially concerned about Mary Shank, who has much to worry her. I wrote quite a long letter to her.

February 29, 1964

Wasted time today reading a book Paul Gallio’s Mrs. ‘Arris Goes to New York, when I should have been working. In the evening went to shower at Lion’s Den for Mary Murphy, who is to marry Bill Voskuhl a week from today. Miserable windy day – from south, March weather; leap year calendar.

March 1, 1964

Lovely spring day – I turned off the furnace in the afternoon; I had a good S. S. class, heard a pretty good sermon. Called people for a meeting of international hospitality committee at my house Tuesday.

March 2, 1964

I cleaned my house. And how it needed it! Worked a little on Guild lesson for Wednesday.

March 3, 1964

Held meeting at my house of the Inter. Hosp. Commee to plan for Easter vacation. In afternoon got my lesson all ready for Guild tomorrow. Busy day tomorrow. In the evening I have chaplain’s part in lodge initiation.

March 4, 1964

Started to walk fast down town and encountered Bill Voskuhl and was thrown hard on pavement. Poor Bill! He was so distressed. I suffered a good bit. Olga Schaefer took me home. The doctor came – no bones broken but much pain all along my torso from waist up. It snowed so they called off Guild & lodge initiation. It cleared up before night but ground covered at first.

March 5, 1964

I suffered pretty bad all night – stayed with Schefers[sic]. In morning felt much better and Olga took me home. Suffering got so bad in the evening I thought some one should have a key to my house, so at 10:00 I called Olga. She came and took me home again.

March 6, 1964

Suffered terribly all night. In morning I called Raymond Bryson and he and Mabel took me to Enid to Dr. Duffy and have X ray No broken bones but had calcium deficiency in backbone. Suffered pretty bad after I got home.

March 7, 1964

Suffered terribly all night and all morning but started feeling better before noon. This evening making back diary entries. People are wonderful. Olga here twice, Gerry brought my dinner, Mabel took my clothes to wash. Alice Potter and Raymond O’Neill & Mrs. Stuerke all here. Roberta Deboard here several times a day. Also Madonna Enmeier here today.

March 8, 1964

Dwight Rusco came by to say his mother died this afternoon. It snowed hard all forenoon, melted off this p.m. I feel about the same – improvement slow if any. People so good – Ramona, Mabel, Claudia, Frances Picken, Fern Seefeldt, Roberta all called

[March 9]

March 9, 1964

March 8 Last night not so bad. I suffered some and got up twice for an hour or so but slept the rest of the time. People are so wonderful. Olga, Mabel, Lavonne Phelan and several others called. Lavonne brought some jello dessert. Dwight Rusco came by and said his mother is very low – the end I think.

March 10, 1964

I had a much better night and felt much better today. Saturday after my bad night I called Dr. Duffy and he promised to put some tablets in the mail to relieve the pain. They came yesterday and I used them and they worked. When the pain got too bad I took one – didn’t get up to try to work it off.

March 11, 1964

Another better night (and better day). After my bad nights it has taken most of the forenoon to get the pain under control. This time I managed it easily. People coming in all the time. They are so wonderful. Among them today were Vernon and Roberta Bostick.

March 12, 1964

Another better night and good day. In the afternoon Mabel and Raymond took me to the graveside service for Mrs. Hubbard. The day was warm and I stood it fine. I still have much company and offers of help though I think busy people can quit me now. I can manage alone.

March 13, 1964

I drove my car to the post office this afternoon. I still have much soreness, but not where it interferes with driving. Pat O’Neill spent the evening with me. I do enjoy his brilliant conversation. He came to see if I want to attend a Civil Liberties meeting March 19.

March 14, 1964

I got a permanent today. My hair was terrible. I had scheduled a permanent for last week, but alas. By bending the right way I managed fine. I drove my own car and even went to the store and got groceries.

March 15, 1964

I taught my S.S. class I had not felt like preparing a lesson and so we read and discussed it together. I also attended church. It seemed as though I had been out a year instead of one week. It was a beautiful warm day. They have landscaped the church lot with evergreens. They are beautiful.

March 16, 1964

Warm day. Shocked to learn that lovely Eva Dean Huffer must have a serious operation. And Alice Draper is in the hospital at Shattuck after an operation Two of my favorite families struck.

March 17, 1964

I’m not much good – no serious pain but quite lame and no strength. I have to lie down every afternoon.

March 18, 1964

I’m still pretty weak. I did make some date bread to take to Leo Leo Draper and the Huffers. It started raining softly this evening and the lights went off. Still off at bedtime. I used candle. Hope I can get along without my electric blanket and pad.

March 19, 1964

Lights came on in the night. Rained all night I think, also in forenoon. Lovely warm soft rain. In p.m. I took my bread to Leo Draper & Huffers. Wheat vivid green & thick on ground. In evening Pat & Mona O’Neill took me to ACLU meeting in O.C. – very interesting. We talked afterwards, got home at 12:20. Weather turned clear and cold. I stood the trip fine, used cushion in car. Didn’t hurt any more than if I had stayed at home.

March 20, 1964

Snowed all morning. I didn’t want to venture out, so Ramona brought my mail and groceries. Ground white. In the afternoon it quit and soon melted. Open house at the library all day. At 2:00 a program in our church basement. Very nice only people were supposed to go to the library afterwards and they didn’t go. I spoke briefly at the program giving history of library. It was Founders Day – March 20, 1936.

March 21, 1964

I’m a long way from well. I manage to do a little and then rest. Still much pain and weakness. Today my small task was to make some date bread for Tues. – club tea and I may have a foreign student visitor. I invited him before I knew how I should feel . It was 24ᵒ last night, heavy white frost this morning.

March 22, 1964

Taught my S.S. class. Didn’t stay for church. Went to bed in the p.m.; then got up and cleaned my house superficially, first time in 3 weeks. I may have a visitor Tuesday. It seems good to be rid of the dust and lint that accumulated since I was hurt hurt.

March 23, 1964

I didn’t hear from the student I invited, so am in dark. But Mabel Bryson, who has invited one student, asked me to bring him to her house for dinner if he comes – says two as easy as one. I promised the day I was before I was hurt to take a car and I will – driving is the easiest thing I do.

March 24, 1964

Almeda Grassman and I drove over and got ten students. The boy I had asked didn’t come, but an extra did. We took them to the Co-op, then to homes. I had dinner at the Brysons with two; then we went to tea at our Club. Then I went to bed. At 8 went to meeting of S.S. teachers at the church. Got thru the day wonderfully – best day yet.

March 25, 1964

Snowed a little and ice froze on windshields this forenoon – cleared off this afternoon. No bad effects from my strenuous day yesterday. Still sore, slept much of afternoon.

March 26, 1964

Service at church this evening but I didn’t go. I promised to show slides to Gerry Schaefer’s American Literature class tomorrow.

March 27, 1964

Beautiful weather. I showed slides to Gerry’s class. An album I ordered of Kennedy speeches came. I played it – found it very fine. the O’Neills and I each ordered one – rather Pat ordered for both of us. Good Friday service, this evening but I did not attend.

March 28, 1964

Nelle Thomas brought Cora June Horsfield and Minnie Nelson (forget her present name) for a brief visit. We knew each other long ago. Mabel and Raymond gave me a record of the “March on Washington” for civil rights. It is very moving – but since then Kennedy has been murdered and still Congress has not acted.

March 29, 1964

Taught my S.S. class & stayed for church – communion service. Pearl Boyce and her sister called briefly in the afternoon. I played my “March on Washington” and my Kennedy album again this evening or rather afternoon.

March 30, 1964

First day I haven’t had to go back to bed in the afternoon but I’m still lame. I wrote a book review that was due March 15, then wrote letters. My best day so far. It sprinkled most of the day – cleared off in late afternoon. The mocking bird is here!

March 31, 1964

Worked on an index for Redlands Press (Mr. Hinkel) – very interesting book by an illiterate – Ellsworth Collings. At least I think this is the day I did it – am writing late. No, I did this later. Guess I wrote constitution for library

April 1, 1964

Went to Guild – Thelma Ficken had very interesting lesson.

April 2, 1964

Perhaps this was day I worked on index. See March 31. Or perhaps wrote letters.

April 3, 1964

Looks like rain this evening. I was very tired. Went to bed early. I have managed to stay up all day all this week, but very tired every evening. Cold day.

April 4, 1964

Apparently rained all night – off and on all day. We are very happy about it.

April 5, 1964

Taught my S.S. class & attended church.

April 6, 1964

Made out my federal income tax – had to write for blanks for state tax. Very tired tonight. I still have so much pain it wears me out by evening.

April 7, 1964

Drove to Stillwater to see govt. profs about civil rights. I want to see if one will come over and explain to our people about bill before Senate. My best day – feeling pretty well this evening.

April 8, 1964

Cold day. Drove to Hennessey to see their 75th anniversary celebration (early so Guthrie can have April 22). Enjoyed dinner of pioneers, open house at their fine library. Pageant in evening directed by an Ohio firm was terrible. Am staying with Lucille Barr.

April 9, 1964

I had a very bad night – apparently because Lucille’s perfectly good bed has no feather bed and I am too sore to be on a mattress. I came back in the morning and spent the day resting. Cold this morning but warming up.

April 10, 1964

I felt really bad today. Perhaps the cold at the pageant settled in all the sore places I have. I was so encouraged Tuesday, but have gone back gain. Ramona took my record player to Enid.

April 11, 1964

I feel better today. Ray and Gladys Six came by briefly – or was it Apr. 10? I am writing late. I made out (and sent off) my state income tax report.

April 12, 1964

I taught my S.S. class & attended church. Terrible day, one of the worst I ever saw. High gale and dust. Unpleasant in morning, increased in ferocity after noon. From south most of the day, then changed to north. Calmed down this evening. Fortunately not cold. I should have been afraid to use the furnace at the height of the gale.

April 13, 1964

Lovely day after yesterday. I felt better worked on index to Cr. Collings’ book and did some small necessary chores in the yard. I am enjoying the mocking bird.

April 14, 1964

Violet Poindexter and her mother came from New Orleans and spent the forenoon with me. In the p.m. I went to club – made preliminary plans for Dr. Carpenter to come from OSU and explain civil rights bill. This evening Burton and Dorine called. It was wonderful to hear their voices on the telephone.

April 15, 1964

I worked on the index to Collings’ book.

April 16, 1964

I cleaned my house superficially and got very tired. It was clean when I had my accident and I have managed twice since to hit the high places. Its last good cleaning was just before I got hurt. It has started raining ton tonight. We need it badly.

April 17, 1964

Rained ¼ inch last night. The Home Dem. Club gave a party to us “senior citizens.” (Silly expression.) It was a very nice party. They had everything ready last fall for a Xmas party and then it stormed. I got a cheap but pretty hat at Catherine Christian’s store – and wore it to the party.

April 18, 1964

It rained a little last night but not much. Cleared off this afternoon. We are having very warm weather. I worked on selecting pictures for talks I am to give tomorrow and Monday – promises I made before got hurt. It will be hard.

April 19, 1964

I taught my S.S. class and drove to Stillwater without staying for church. Am visiting Alice Moffitt In the afternoon I showed pictures of England to an A.AUW international relations group. I was so good to myself and Alice was so good to me that I got through the day without getting tired. Feel wonderful tonight.

April 20, 1964

Drove to Ponca this forenoon – it rained on me day off and on. Had lunch with Mrs. Ross & Mrs. Dixon. In the afternoon showed slides I took behind the Iron Curtain. Hard drive back because of high wind. Got home at five tired, but rested a while, and went to community meeting to plan visit of Dr. Carpenter of OSU to explain Civil Rights Bill now before Senate.

April 21, 1964

In the morning I wrote letters and Winnie and I talked about Dr. Carpenter – also I wrote newspaper articles about him. In the afternoon I went to visit Mrs. Hawkins, first time since my injury. Found her improved. In the evening I started to put my slides back in their cases and had so much pain I had to go to bed.

April 22, 1964

Finished making slips of index. Put them on the table and worked at alphabetizing them. The position hurt my back so I had to go to bed. I can’t stand to lean forward and work. Bad cloud went north. Later – tornado at Fairmont, Billings, Tonkawa.

April 23, 1964

Worked on typing index of Collings book. Had to lie down twice but rested enough so I watered my flowers. They have needed it sadly but this is the first time I have been able to do it.

April 24, 1964

[No entry]

April 25, 1964

Ralph Cooper came to visit me this afternoon. In the evening I went to a shower at church for Sherry Tarrant and Vernon Ficken, two wonderful young people who will be married soon – with my complete approval.

April 26, 1964

Taught my S.S. class. Rev. John gone so Mr. Pendleton of Philips preached. Fine sermon. My back got very tired resting it on the hard seat back – I lay down an hour before I started dinner. Wilson Talbot called with Glendora Hammer. She looks surprisingly young and vital. I haven’t seen her for about fifty years – not since about 1913. Spent a very pleasant evening with the young O’Neills.

April 27, 1964

I learned by accident that the young Givens family vacated my house yesterday Friday without telling me. (Their April rent is paid.) I found the house very filthy. Got a man to haul off junk, engaged Dorothy Elmore to paper all the rooms, must have cleaning done also. Ann Givens was a terrible housekeeper.

April 28, 1964

Selected paper for my rent house. Ordered a screen door. Felt a disturbing symptom so went to Enid to see the Dr. Duffy. He said it is not unusual with the hormones I have been taking the past two months – to stop for a week, then start again and come back in two more months. Jim O’Neill very low – in hospital at Enid.

April 29, 1964

I am very fortunate getting Dorothy Elmore to paper my rent house and Roberta Allen to clean and paint the woodwork. They will start tomorrow. The cleaning is a real job. The house is filthy. Roberta is so pretty and gifted. I hate to have her wade into it.

April 30, 1964

Dr. Carpenter spoke to a very good crowd turn-out at the schoolhouse this evening. I hope his very able presentation dissipated some of the lies that are being circulated about the Civil Rights Bill. The audience was very responsive and asked a good many questions.

May 1, 1964

May Fellowship Day – at Xn church this year. We had luncheon. (I took chicken dumplings.) The service was mainly a very fine picture show about equal employment for Negroes. Woodrow Winburn took off my porch shingles to put on new ones and we had a lovely rain all afternoon and evening. It leaked some but not much.

May 2, 1964

Woodrow started shingling as soon as the roof was dry. It has some old wood shingles that were left on, but it did leak yesterday. A violent rain would have drenched everything in my closet – bedding, books, clothing. Woodrow covered the unfinished part with a tarp fastened down with bricks.

May 3, 1964

I taught my S.S. class and attended church. Got very tired and spent the p.m.in bed. It didn’t rain but it might tonight. I am glad the tarp is on the unshingled part. My peonies started blooming. I had two to take to church. Used iris for the alter vases – not enough peonies.

May 4, 1964

Woodrow finished the shingles, so now it can rain. He has some trimming up to do. Dorothy Elmore finished painting the rent house Saturday. I paid her today $50.75.I finished my index.

May 5, 1964

Roberta Allen finished cleaning and painting the rent house. This was a very bad day with a high wind. I attended a meeting of the library board this morning.

May 6, 1964

There was a fine rain last night – 1½ inches, the most moisture we have had all spring. Today was lovely. My peonies, iris, and old fashioned yellow roses are lovely. I attended Guild at Olga Schaefer’s.

May 7, 1964

Went to Guild “workshop” (silly name) at Kingfisher. Enjoyed it very much – the most interesting one I ever attended (in fact the only interesting one). It was cloudy and threatened rain but didn’t do it. In the evening Burton called me and said he and Dorine were coming to visit me this week end. Yippee! I rented my house – young couple named Roberts.

May 8, 1964

I did some things getting ready for Burton and Dorine but didn’t clean my house. I can’t stand much at a time. Have to stop and rest. They will leave after Burton’s work day is over at five – arrive late. Bless them. It Long and hard a trip to visit me.

May 9, 1964

Burton and Dorine arrived a little after midnight. We have visited a lot but we all slept awhile this afternoon. In the evening I showed pics of England. We are not going to church tomorrow. They went with me to arrange some peonies in the vases on the altar.

May 10, 1964

I had a dinner engagement with the Hinkels at Stillwater, so we all planned to leave at twelve. But it started raining a little so they left 20 minutes earlier. When I left at twelve it was a heavy downpour. I enjoyed my dinner and visit with the Hinkels – met Mrs. Siegal there. Drove home in a very heavy rain. Still raining. Burton and Dorine helped me so much I am scarcely tired.

May 11, 1964

Cool day – cold in fact. The clouds cleared away and the sky is so blue and everything lovely. I cleaned my house. Didn’t clean it before the Halsteds came – was trying to take it easy and I knew they would understand. They told me to take it easy.

May 12, 1964

The Marshall Woman’s Club met at my house today. First we went to the schoolhouse to see a picture. Cool beautiful day. This evening for the first time I have enjoyed the spring. Before this I was too tired – also the weather unpleasant, too dry and windy. Jim O’Neill died last night.

May 13, 1964

May 14 I reported on a MS I am reading read for the Uni. Of Okla, Press. I still have to take things slowly and rest often. Stet Entry O.K. for May 13.

May 14, 1964

May 15 Attended Jim O’Neill’s funeral at the Catholic Church. It rained a little this morning but not much. We have had real spring weather ever since the rain Sunday (2½ in.) – birds singing grass starting to choke out the weeds on the lawn, flowers blooming, air sweet and pure.

May 15, 1964

See last entry for May 15 May 14, 1964 I took Winnie Branen to Stillwater to look up some things in the college library – some to help us in our library here. It threatened rain but didn’t.

May 16, 1964

Lovely day but starting to get warm again. I kept the library this afternoon.

May 17, 1964

I had a fine S.S. class. At the church service, Barbara and Ronnie Schaefer were confirmed also a communion service. The h.s. graduates wore their caps and gowns – their baccalaureate service was this evening but I didn’t attend. Went to a church assn. meeting at O.C. in the afternoon – bot back at ten. Rode with Paul Schler and delegates from Carrier and Goltry.

May 18, 1964

Attended meeting of the Library Board in the afternoon. We can get a fine building used by Hennessey school and now surplus. Cost is $2200. If only we can raise the money.

May 19, 1964

I drove to Stillwater to get Dr. Garnier to remove a tiny wart from the edge of my eyelid. Staying overnight with Alice Carlson. Went with her to monthly pot luck and business meeting of her S.S. class at the Baptist church.

May 20, 1964

Went to visit Grace and Ruth Hammond in the morning (They rest in the P.M.). Then drove home. A little tired. The removal of the wart was not serious at all but the eye is a sensitive place.

May 21, 1964

Wrote some letters but in general I wasted the day. I am reading The Mountain Meadows Massacre by Juanita Brooks, and an interesting book has a very demoralizing effect on me if I read when I should work.

May 22, 1964

My new renter, attractive Mrs. Chas. Roberts came to ask me about churches. I told her of all of them and of course invited her to ours, also to Club meeting. They will move in Sunday. They will be an assett [sic] to the town. He works for Dale Wilson.

May 23, 1964

Edna Stuerke Fraker died this morning. I drove to Enid this P.M. to see Ethel Hawkins. She has improved greatly since moving. I knew she had gained strength and weight & today I learned she had gained 13 lbs. But she is very dissatisfied because she has to follow the doctor’s orders. Says people have lost all their freedom. Mean windy day. I am amazed at how ripe the wheat is.

May 24, 1964

Lovely day. We had our annual outdoor church service and picnic at Pete Ficken’s. Very nice. In the evening the young O’Neills took me to O.C. t see a movie, “The Cardinal.” Very fine we got back at about one A.M.

May 25, 1964

Hot day. Winnie Branen, Mabel Bryson, Leota Windler and I drove to the City to Edna Fraker’s funeral in the afternoon. My air conditioner quit on the way down. Pauline Curry was going with us but fell when getting into the car and skinner her knee. Some barley came to the elevator.

Library Me had our annual outdoor church service and picnic at Pete Ficken’s. Very nice. In the evening the Young O’Neills took me to O.C. to see a movie “The Cardinal.” Very fine. We go back at about one A.M.

May 26, 1964

We had our final melting and annual picnic of the Marshall Woman’s Club at Winnie Branen’s. The new officers were installed. I took up my new duties as reporter. I hate it but we all have to join in and work. Too few to allow any of us to loaf. My car air conditioner needed only a 10¢ fuse.

May 27, 1964

WE have been having hot dry weather, but last night there was a “bank,” as my mother used to call it, in the west. Today it was cloudy and we had several quick, April-type showers. Not much water FELL. Della Post died this morning of cancer. A year ago she was a strong vital farm woman, active in clubs, industrious at home.

May 28, 1964

Today was really cold. I would have used the furnace except that I had turned off my pilot light. I lighted my oven for warmth. In the afternoon I helped Winnie unpack a shipment of books for the library. In the evening I worked in the cemetery. The country is beautiful with the low sun shining across the ripe wheat.

May 29, 1964

Attended Della’s funeral in the Xn Church at 10:30. It rained off and on and was cloudy all day except that the sun broke through a blue sky with fluffy clouds just as we came out of the church. I did not go to the cemetery but I hope the services there was over before the rain started again. Cold all day.

May 30, 1964

Tired of depending on the oven for warmth, so lighted the furnace. It rained all day. I didn’t go to the cemetery to decorate my graves, though most of the people did. I sewed all day – had to have some underwear. I had lilies and clematis – also peonies kept in the refrigerator – which I would have taken to the cemetery.

May 31, 1964

I had a wonderful S.S. class. Good crowd at preaching service. It will slow down when harvest starts. I used some of my cut flowers in the church – then took them to the cemetery after church. I have 12 graves there. It cleared off this morning and was a beautiful day.

June 1, 1964

Lovely cool day. Blue sky, fresh air, bright sun. And the mocking bird! Ralph called. He had been at the cemetery. Had car trouble, so failed to get there earlier.

June 2, 1964

[No entry]

June 3, 1964

I went to Guild at Friend home. Good meeting, Lavonne Phelan leader. I took Lois Roberts, the lovely young woman in my rent house.

June 4, 1964

If it doesn’t rain tonight the harvest will start tomorrow. A little barley came in more than a week ago – no combining since.

June 5, 1964

We had a rain last night – only .13 inch but enough to stop the harvest. A load or two of barley came in late this afternoon.

June 6, 1964

Harvest started this afternoon – going strong by night. Alice Carlson brought Dr. Rebekah Pate over to see it. They had dinner with me, then on to Alice’s brother’s near Waukomis. I wish they had stayed here for we could have given them a good show A long line of truck trucks on Main Street.

June 7, 1964

Hot windy day. Summer church hours started, S.S. at 9 which is always bad, then everybody tired so small attendance at S.S. A little better at church. Harvest going strong, long line of trucks still coming in at sundown

June 8, 1964

Hot day with very high wind. Good for harvest but hard on the people. Harvest in full blast. My regal lilies are glorious.

June 9, 1964

Hot windy day. Harvest progressing fast. At 9:30 this evening they were still combining (with lights) in Roy Beeby’s field across the road. I don’t know when they stopped. Big trucks still rushing to town at 9:30 loaded with wheat.

June 10, 1964

Hot day but that terrible wind has slowed down. Perfect harvest day, only dew in the morning. Combine running and wheat coming in from Roy Beeby’s field at 9:30 P.M. and I don’t know how much later. Senate fillibuster on Civil Rights Bill broken!

June 11, 1964

Lovely rain early this morning. Bright cool day. Rain not good for harvest but fine for my flower garden (so-called). About 75% of the grain is harvested. I think they got back in the field later this P.M. It won’t delay things much.

June 12, 1964

Another lovely light rain in the forenoon. Not good for harvest but very pleasant. In the afternoon the sun shone and it was a beautiful cool, bright day. I went out to see Eva Dean Huffer about a Guild lesson and Don showed me a new machine for dropping hay in windrows.

June 13, 1964

Another cool, lovely day, but no rain. I do not think it became dry enough for combining.

June 14, 1964

Hard shower last night – .6 inch. A quick lovely April shower, dusting church. Cleared off in afternoon. I taught my S.S. class and attended church. Lovely cool day.

June 15, 1964

They started combining this afternoon. I saw quite a line of trucks on the street this evening – nearly a block long. They worked into the night. Clouds all around but none here.

June 16, 1964

It didn’t rain today either. I am sure they must have got a lot of harvesting done this afternoon. I imagine most of it is done now. Nice day, not hot. Lovely and cool this evening.

June 17, 1964

No rain, lovely day. I have finally got time to make a final organization and identification of the slides I too made on our 1962 trip. Used notes I took at the time – also booklets, folders, etc.

June 18, 1964

Hot day with high wind. Unpleasant but just right for harvesting a few miles north where they had heavier rains than we did and the combines mired down. I continued on my slides but shall not have time to finish the collection.

June 19, 1964

Worked a little on slides. Did some odds and ends to get ready for trip to Wichita tomorrow. Heard dreadful news. “Red” Hall worked with his combine outfit in Kansas Monday. Went to doctor Tuesday and found he has a hopeless case of cancer. He is such an engaged, hard-working person, but has been losing flesh.

June 20, 1964

Drove to Wichita to meeting of Conference Committee on Xn Social Action – fine meeting – we really got down to business. Hot day – high wind. I got home tired. Found four bins of our elevator burst from defective structure or spontaneous combustion. It happened at 11 or 11:30 last night. Fortunately nobody there.

June 21, 1964

Taught my S.S. class and attended church. In the afternoon worked on minutes of meeting yesterday. (I drew the job of secy.) All the talk is of the damaged elevator – 80,000 bushels of wheat spilled – so thankful nobody was under it. Hot day – and so dry!

June 22, 1964

Started worked on a MS by two men (Ruby & Brown) from Washington state [sic]. Worked hard but am enjoying it. This evening some broken clouds came over and there was a very hard wind. Lightning in the distance. Anyhow it is getting cooler.

June 23, 1964

June 25. I turned two pages and wrote June 23 on June 25 page. Cool dewey [sic] morning – lovely bright day. I used the air conditioner towards the end of the afternoon. I worked on the MS.

June 24, 1964

Lovely bright day – cool in morning, not very hot in P.M. Early this morning I took pictures of the damaged elevator and the spilled wheat which a Texas crew is salvaging. It will cost 25¢ a bu. In afternoon went to Enid to see Mrs. Hawkins. She is improving all the time. I worked on the MS. in the forenoon.

June 25, 1964

Woke up this morning and found the ground muddy. It rained 1½ in., the most this year. We are very happy. Lovely cool day – good day to work on the MS. In the afternoon Leota Windler, Olga Schaefer, and I went through all the church library See June 23 page.

June 26, 1964

Another lovely morning and nice day. I went to Guthrie with Leota Windler to call on the Shrages. Mr. S’s mind has failed until he is as dependent on his wife as a baby. I worked all forenoon on the MS. I am enjoying the hard work.

June 27, 1964

Worked hard all morning on MS. In the P.M. got my hair washed and set, studied my S.S. lesson, and other odds and ends.

June 28, 1964

Taught my S.S. class and heard a fine sermon by Dr. Norman Jacobs of Phillips who is filling the pulpit when Rev. John is away. In the afternoon Allie and Lula came by. On way from Calif. to daughter Lois in Penna. Ralph was with them, also Allie’s Lula’s sister, Mabel, from Hennessey.

June 29, 1964

Somehow felt sluggish all day and didn’t accomplish much on the MS.

June 30, 1964

One of the best days I have had for a long time. Felt wonderful all day. Worked on MS – then cleaned north half of house. It was cloudy all day, sprinkled a little once, showers collecting all around this evening.

July 1, 1964

It rained last night but not much water fell – better than nothing. Worked on MS in morning. Went to Guild in P.M. at Winnie Schaefer’s. Eva Dean Huffer had fine lesson. Called on Mrs. Stuerke this evening.

July 2, 1964

Worked on MS in morning. In P.M. went to Enid to report to Dr. Duffy. He lightened the hormone and calcium dosage. Stopped and saw Mrs. Hawkins. She didn’t complain at all. She has been a very cheerful uncomplaining person till she got off on the wrong foot recently.

July 3, 1964

Worked on MS this morning. Went out to Elsie Schaefer’s in the P.M. and she gave me a permanent. Hot weather these days, but still lovely in the mornings.

July 4, 1964

Worked all day on the MS. It was good to hear the church bells ring at noon. A new custom and I like it.

July 5, 1964

Taught my S.S class and heard another fine sermon by Dr. Jacobs.

July 6, 1964

I made no entry for the week of July 6-11. The weather was terribly hot. It is usually bad in July but this week was worse than

July 7, 1964

usual. It is terribly dry. I water things but the sun and wind scorch the leaves of even hardy shrubs like the lilacs and

July 8, 1964

even some of the smaller branches die. I worked all week on the MS and because of my air conditioner I was very

July 9, 1964

comfortable. The grass is dying on the lawn. Most of the trees are all right because it takes more than one dry season

July 10, 1964

to take all the moisture out of the subsoil.

July 11, 1964

I taught my S.S. class and heard a good sermon by Dr. Hatt.

July 12, 1964

It was cloudy this morning and during church there was a quick hard shower. If only it had kept on. Cooler all day. I am getting a little annoyed at our pastor. He doesn’t preach well but he can’t help that. Only he doesn’t try. Today his sermon was 10 min. long. Then he dismissed us. He simply hadn’t prepared.

July 13, 1964

Really cold last night, lovely cool day. But there apparently is no prospect for more rain. In the afternoon I went to Leota Windler’s and we worked out the Guild lessons for next year.

July 14, 1964

Still fairly cool.

July 15, 1964

Hot weather from here on. I have been listening it to the Republican convention this week. I am not a Republican but I am very unhappy

July 16, 1964

about it. Surely that sort of reaction can not capture the electorate. But there is always the danger. And besides we need

July 17, 1964

two two parties with intelligence. I heard the inane speech of Eisenhower. Reminds me of a remark attributed to Lincoln – the

July 18, 1964

most words compressed into the fewest thoughts I ever heard. Nixon made a “harmony” speech that was brilliant. He is intelligent. But it was completely

July 19, 1964

insincere insincere. The acceptance speeches of Miller and Goldwater were idiotic.

July 20, 1964

Another very hot week. The temperature at Kingfisher, says the Oklahoman, went up to 111ᵒ some days probably even more

July 21, 1964

here. And not a drop of moisture. I water things every day, but no matter how much I wet the ground the leaves burn

July 22, 1964

and the branches die. I may lose my favorite rose. All the leaves are dead and some of the branches. I have worked all the time on the

July 23, 1964

Moses manuscript. I can do it fairly well on account of the air conditioner.

July 24, 1964

July 25 Learned that Leota Windler’s father died Thursday. Will have the funeral Sunday in our church at 4:30. The Women are serving the noon meal to the family and visiting relatives.

July 25, 1964

July 25th entry is on July 24 page.

July 26, 1964

Taught my S.S. class and attended church. I am getting annoyed at the minister His entire sermon was a boresome narrative of a movie he had seen. People used to do that back in 1908 when the “nickelodeon” was a novelty. I went to the church at 4:30 only to find I had been misinformed. The funeral was at 2:30.

July 27, 1964

This morning at about 4 I heard it thunder and a few drops of rain fell. It was lovely and cool in the morning but as hot as ever during the rest of the day.

July 28, 1964

I had a bad night – too windy and too hot – and rested today instead of working.

July 29, 1964

[No entry]

July 30, 1964

Another terrible hot week. I worked on the MS all week. No relief from the heat and drought.

July 31, 1964

[No entry]

August 1, 1964

Burton called me this evening. It was so good to hear his voice.

August 2, 1964

I had a very small S.S. class. Rev John preached a well prepared sermon. Perhaps he had some reason for his lack of preparation the past few weeks. In the P.M. Pat O’Neill took me to the planetarium and then to dinner at a cafeteria. I enjoyed it very much. Ramona was not feeling well and she insisted on our going.

August 3, 1964

The worst day we have had. Alice Moffitt, Dr. Rebekah Pate, and Idress Cash came in the evening and I showed them picks of Russia. I couldn’t get the temperature in the house down below 90ᵒ all evening.

August 4, 1964

A day like yesterday. This is the worst weather we have ever had except the terrible summer of ’36 – and it may get as bad as that before August is over. The thermometer goes up to 110ᵒ or 112ᵒ and is not even cool in the evening.

August 5, 1964

Attended Guild at Mabel Bryson’s. Fine lesson by Alma Friend. Terribly hot day. I am writing by the air conditioner at 7:00 P.M. and when I step outside it is like the breath of a furnace.

August 6, 1964

Terrible weather. Every day the thermometer goes up to 110ᵒ or more. It stands at 100ᵒ at eight in the evening. None of our usual cool evenings and nights. There are often clouds in the distance but no rain

August 7, 1964

Rain! About two o’clock hard rain 1.53 in. with much wind. Lovely cool day. It makes one feel th in harmony with nature – not an enemy.

August 8, 1964

Lovely cool morning – not too hot day – lovely cool evening. The kind of weather one enjoys. There are robins all over the lawn. I don’t know where they came from. Ants digging. Cicadas singing.

August 9, 1964

Lovely cool morning. I taught my S.S. class – There was no preaching, Rev. John was directing a youth camp. Nice day. In the evening the young Bostick family (bless them) invited all us old women in the block for cake and ice cream on their lawn. Nice.

August 10, 1964

A pleasant gentle rain came last night but I think not much water fell. It was cool this morning – got hot during the day, but within reason.

August 11, 1964

Cloudy part of the day and not so hot. Cooler this evening. I have a sore on my hand that doesn’t heal so went to see Dr. Duffy. He took a piece for a pathologist. He Xrayed my back and it is really filling in with bony structure. Good news. I went to see Mrs. Hawkins. Thought she looked not so well as usual.

August 12, 1964

It was cloudy and actually cold today – so cold I closed the windows and put on more clothes. It was wonderful to work. I feel scarcely tired at all tonight

August 13, 1964

Cloudy and cold all morning. (At noon with all the doors and windows closed the thermometer in my dining room said 69ᵒ) It warmed up a little in the afternoon.

August 14, 1964

Cold and cloudy again. There was a hard shower in the afternoon, and is raining hard this evening. I caught water in my cistern – the first time for a year.. I didn’t catch the May 10 rain because of new tarred roof on my porch. Learned the sore on my hand is a skin cancer. Will have it treated Monday.

August 15, 1964

Lovely day. So cold I closed the kitchen and kept the oven going all morning so my bread would rise. Warmer in the afternoon.

August 16, 1964

Went to S.S. (taught my class). Rev. John really preached a good sermon. I learned the church council met last night and asked him to resign. He and his wife are a pitiable couple – do not seem to understand how to work at their jobs. In the afternoon went to Wichita with Harold & Lavonne Phelan and Bob Schaefer to a “seminar” on the S.S. courses.

August 17, 1964

I went to Enid to see doctor, but he thought my hand was O.K. Red Hall died yesterday. So shocking. He was such a virile person. Less than two months ago he was combining wheat. He never lost his humor and his high spirits during his illness. His family was equally brave.

August 18, 1964

Hard rain last night. So lovely this evening – bright sun, clean cool air, leaves coming out on shrubs like in spring. I went to Red Hall’s funeral today. His brave family!

August 19, 1964

Another nice day. I worked as usual on the MS. It turned out to be a bigger job than I realized when I undertook it.

August 20, 1964

Cool cloudy day. I finished the MS. Somehow I felt rather sad when I put it in the box. I became so well acquainted with the people and the places it was like saying good-by to friends and familiar scenes. My resurrection lilies are blooming – result of the rain.

August 21, 1964

Cool all day, actually cold in the morning. I cleaned my house (how it needed it!) starting yesterday and finishing today. My yard is lovely and green.

August 22, 1964

[No entry]

August 23, 1964

I taught my S.S. class – good attendance for summer – and attended church. Rev. John preached better than usual. Nice day

August 24, 1964

[No entry]

August 25, 1964

A hard rain coming straight down out of a small cloud – some hail fell. We really needed the rain. I listened to Dem. Natl. convention

August 26, 1964

We had two hard showers today. Lovely weather. I listened to the Dem. Natl. Conv. on radio. So glad President chose Hubert Humphrey as his running mate.

August 27, 1964

I went to the Pat O’Neill’s to watch on TV this evening. Saw young Bobby Kennedy’s ordeal as he tried to make a speech preliminary to a film of his brother’s life and the crowd gave him an ovation. The film was very moving. Ramona cried outright. Heard Humphrey’s acceptance speech – also Johnson’s. Adlai Stevenson gave a tribute to Eleanor Roosevelt. Best speech of the convention. Nobody but John Kennedy has ever approached him in thought and word. After I got home a rain with wind. The Krouses came to see me this forenoon.

August 28, 1964Lovely cool morning with sunshine and clean air. Nice all day. Word has come to us that Grif Thompson died. Poor Daisy!

August 29, 1964

[No entry]

August 30, 1964

Sprinkled a little this morning – warm in afternoon. I taught my S.S. class and attended church. Went to Griff Thompson’s funeral in the afternoon. Rode to the cemetery with the Hap Shorts and the Vernon Bosticks

August 31, 1964

[No entry]

September 1, 1964

I showed slides of England to Gerry Schaefer’s Engl. lit. class this morning. Found Lois Roberts is really ill. I wish she would go to the hospital. I called on Mary Voskuhl to invite her to club.

September 2, 1964

Women’s Guild met with Leota Windler today – fine lesson by Frances Ficken on her work with Welfare Dept. Mrs. Young buried today so Guild met late, after the funeral.

September 3, 1964

[No entry for 1964]

September 4, 1964

I went to Enid to see Mrs. Hawkins. Found her much improved but of course almost helpless with arthritis and almost blind.

September 5, 1964

My young friend, Edward Oliver, came up from Guthrie to see me today. This whole week has been very warm but there was a brief shower this morning.

September 6, 1964

I taught my S.S. class and attended church. Rev. John is doing his best with the his pastorate and I feel unhappy about his failure here. He and Marceil are lovable people and they need help which we have failed to give them.

September 7, 1964

Nothing much happened; I visited the Brysons in the evening. The sky is red these days at sunset and sunrise just as it was a year ago.

September 8, 1964

Our Marshall Woman’s Club had its luncheon and first meeting. Madonna showed slides of the World’s Fair at New York. In the evening I went with Pat and Ramona O’Neill, Vernon and Roberta Bostic [sic], and Bill Smith to a Democratic rally where Fred Harris spoke. I am much impressed with Harris.

September 9, 1964

I was tired and didn’t accomplish much.

September 10, 1964

It is getting very dry. I carried some water to plants that were suffering but didn’t watch everything with the hose because there is what my parents used to call a “bank” in the west. It probably won’t rain but I’ll wait one more day.

September 11, 1964

It did rain. Nearly all night – 3½ inches. I am very happy about it. It is really cold today. I’d really like a fire this evening. I attended a meeting of the Library Board.

September 12, 1964

[No entry]

September 13, 1964

Taught my S.S. class and attended church. Rev. John is really taking his preaching seriously. I wish they would give him another trial. In the P.M. I went to Guthrie with the Schaefer girls to see the Schrages. Found Mr. Schrage clear in mind and improving in body.

September 14, 1964

Drove out to see Mrs. Kusik to see about her retouching an enlarged print of Charles, Janie, and Cindy Burchardt.

September 15, 1964

Rained a little today.

September 16, 1964

Rained last night and today. Not much water.

September 17, 1964

Rained a little today. Went to Enid to see doctor about the akin cancer on my hand. He used electric needle & said come back in 2 wks. I also hunted curtains for my kitchen – no luck.

September 18, 1964

Meeting of Inter. Hosp. Commee at my house this morning.

September 19, 1964

[No entry]

September 20, 1964

Late entry. But I know I taught my S.S. class and attended church. In the evening we had a very happy family night at the church – no supper, just cookies and coffee.

September 21, 1964

[No entry]

September 22, 1964

It rained last night. Our Marshall Woman’s Club met this afternoon at Margaret Perdue’s. Good meeting. Ramona O’Neill was in charge of the program.

September 23, 1964

Bob Schaefer and I went to Norman to the governor’s conference on libraries. (Bob took his car.) Four of us were invited but the other two couldn’t go. It was a good meeting.

September 24, 1964

Bill Conaghan and another man from Tonkawa, Ralph Casey called. Mr. C. is a great reader & brought some books for me to autograph. Then Rev. Bob Ruch called. He and Joan are visiting in the community and both intended to call but the babies got to tired she had to put them to bed.

September 25, 1964

Pat & Ramona O’Neill (bless them) asked me to go with them to the City to hear the President speak. We stood packed about four hours but it was worth it. Thrilled to see the presidential flag and seal on the platform. Of course I am tired but so thankful I got to go Joe drove his car.

September 26, 1964

Mrs. Stuerke wanted to attend a luncheon at Penn Square for the people who have signed up for the apartments for elderly people which will be completed next summer. Ginger Hitt and I were invited. Ginger took her car. We had a good day – ran into a very heavy rain just before we got to Marshall.

September 27, 1964

Cold day. I taught my S.S. class and attended church service. In the P.M. the Quincy Rusco’s came to see me. I am very grateful to them for the long trip.

September 28, 1964

Cold day. I could have worked more than I did (I did bake some date bread for Vernon Bostick who has been down with his back. Had a nice visit with Roberta and girls when I took it to the house.

September 29, 1964

Beautiful day. Ramona O’Neill took me out on crooked hill roads east of Marshall to the farm where Pat is beginning his wheat planting. It was delightful. She wanted the trip out there and took the men some soft drinks.

September 30, 1964

Went with group of Woman’s Guild members to a retreat at Roman Nose State Park. Fine service. Beautiful surroundings.

October 1, 1964

I went to Stillwater and got some new kitchen curtains. They look very nice. I have had a hard time getting some that suit me. These do, though not quite as pretty as my old ones, which I made myself.

October 2, 1964

Wrote letters, etc. Man came and treated my garage for termites. He is probably a crook but I let him do it. We are having lovely weather.

October 3, 1964

[No entry]

October 4, 1964

Taught my S.S. class & attended church. In the P.M. went with the Webers & Paul Schler to fall meeting of Assembly at Carrier. Had a chance to get together with members of the committee on Xn Social action.

October 5, 1964

See Oct. 7 – I turned two pages. Oct. 7. I drove to Stillwater to get a picture of Charles Burchardt and family framed. The picture was taken at his ordination and this one will be put in the pastor’s study.

October 6, 1964

[No entry for 1964]

October 7, 1964

I can’t remember how the Drove to Enid to see doctor about little sore on my hand. I know skin cancers are not serious but I’ll be glad to get rid of it. Also called on Mrs. Hawkins. In the evening Rev. John called. He is very happy over the Council’s decision to request his resignation.

October 8, 1964

[No entry]

October 9, 1964

I drove over to Stillwater and got my framed picture. After I got home I showed it to Raymond and Mabel. They liked it.

October 10, 1964

[No entry]

October 11, 1964

I taught my S.S. class and attended preaching service. Threatened rain and did sprinkle some. In the p.m. I went out to John Hammers’ to meet a Canadian guest named Tuft. He is very interesting and so are John & Glendora.

October 12, 1964

Lovely Roberta Allen came to help me (actually did most of the wash) and we (that is, she) cleaned and waxed the kitchen and washed the outside of the windows. Leaving most of the house till Woodrow gets wheat planted. Lovely rain this evening. It was getting dry. Of course it will stop wheat planting.

October 13, 1964

Meeting of International Hospitality Com. at my house in forenoon. Good plans made for Nov. 14. Went to Club in p.m. Good program. In evening went to see Pat & Ramona O’Neill. Had fine visit. They gave me a lovely booklet printed in Ireland of Pres. Kennedy’s visit there in 63.

October 14, 1964

Wrote article for paper about Club. Also – and this was more trouble – a report to dist. club officers on what we have done in “promoting Oklahoma.” People will try to plant planned to plant wheat this p.m. if possible.

October 15, 1964

Worried about resignation of Khrushchev. We were finally getting along with Russia. Also disgusted at morality scandal about Walter Jenkins – afraid it will hurt Johnson in election. Spent evening with the O’Neills, Clara McCluney & her husband called.

October 16, 1964

[No entry]

October 17, 1964

Visit with Nelle Thomas this afternoon. Rev. John called this morning and stayed for quite a visit.

October 18, 1964

Mission Festival with dinner at the church. Dr. Huff of Phillips spoke morning and afternoon. Very fine.

October 19, 1964

Roberta Allen came and varnished my six dining chairs. They are unbelievably new looking.

October 20, 1964

A sore spot came into my abdomen this p.m. I am afraid it may be serious. This morning I had a lovely drive with Ramona O’Neill up into the hills east of town. I did some preliminary work dismantling my study – also waxed my hall floor.

October 21, 1964

Had some fever last night – wondered if I should call the dr., but fever went down in forenoon so I didn’t. Up again this evening. (Only 100ᵒ) Abdomen quite sore. Roberta came and moved everything out of my study and waxed the floor. Woodrow will come tomorrow to tear off plaster. Warm lovely day.

October 22, 1964

Woodrow tore the plaster off my study. Geo. Hawkins tol Voskuhl told Mrs. Hawkins had had a fall and was very low. I went to Enid to see the dr. He said my trouble was colitis & gave me some medicine. I stopped and looked in on Mrs. H. but she was asleep and I did not wake her. The dr. told me to come back in a week if the trouble does not clear up. Warm day.

October 23, 1964

Learned that lively vital Mrs. Beeby died Wednesday. She has been a part of this community since her father took a claim in the Cherokee Strip. The sulpha drug the doctor gave me worked wonders. Slept all night – no fever – soreness leaving. Woodrow installed the sheetrock except for a few irregular pieces.

October 24, 1964

Woodrow working on walls. I worked on a School of Missions lesson I am to give tomorrow. The subject Spanish Americans. My colitis is still getting better. I see in entry above I was hoping Woodrow would come last year. He didn’t make it.

October 25, 1964

Taught my S.S. class and attended church. Mrs. Beeby’s funeral was in the afternoon but I did not attend. I loved her very much, but know there would be no room in the church. In the evening I taught my missions course. It rained ½ inch last night and a little more this evening. Learned Claudia Ahrnsbrak had a heart attack and her daughter took her home yesterday.

October 26, 1964

Woodrow went over the walls again, smoothing the seams in the sheetrock. It will dry and be ready for paint tomorrow. Learned Claudia Ahrnsbrak is in the hospital. Had heart attack.

October 27, 1964

Woodrow got the walls painted. Now the room is all finished ready to move in. It looks lovely. I cleaned the floor carefully after his work was done. Ready to clean window and varnish woodwork.

October 28, 1964

Roberta varnished the woodwork in my study, also the bookcase, which in 60 years had begun to need it. The room looks lovely. The warm weather is just right for varnishing. We turn off the furnace, even the pilot light.

October 29, 1964

Nov.1, 1964 Turned too many pages for Oct. 29. Taught my S.S. class, attended church. In evening conducted mission study. Made a bobble because I couldn’t find the film I wanted to use. Finally found it in my pocket.

October 30, 1964

Nov. 2, 1964 Woodrow had to go to Guthrie today, so didn’t work. I went to Enid to see Ethel. Found her better but very dissatisfied. In the evening went to the O’Neills to see last TV of campaign – Goldwater folksy chat with his family, Johnson really eloquent – most eloquent speech he ever made.

October 31, 1964

Nov. 3, 1964 Went to Claudia’s funeral at the Catholic Church this morning. Appreciated the new use of English in the ritual. A fine sermon by the priest. Woody got the wall ready for the paint. Hard rain in late P.M. – 2 inches. Very happy over repudiation of Goldwater, also happy that Harris was elected to Senate over the fine football coach Bud Wilkinson. I stayed up till eleven waiting to hear Goldwater concede, but he didn’t. Did hear Harris’s victory speech. Failed to get Bud’s concession.

November 1, 1964

Oct. 29, 1964. Turned too many pages. Roberta helped me – rather she did the work and I helped her. We put all the furniture back in my study. Then we removed all the furniture from my bedroom and waxed the floor.

November 2, 1964

Oct. 30, 1964 – turned too many pages Woodrow knocked all the plaster off my bedroom and put on much of the sheetrock. We are having lovely warm weather and this is a great help.

November 3, 1964

Oct. 31, 1964 – turned too many pages Learned that Claudia Ahrnsbrak died this morning. Her roses are blooming so beautifully where she tended them so carefully. It makes me sad to see them. Woodrow finished with the sheetrock and plastered the cracks with the goo he uses. Warm day. Children came for treats.

November 4, 1964

Woodrow painted but didn’t quite finish. I went to Women’s Guild at church in the afternoon. Woodrow finished the painting but had some work in putting back the furnace grate, etc.

November 5, 1964

Roberta waxed the bedroom floor. Then Woodrow came and finished up while Roberta also worked in the room. She got the varnishing done, also varnished the dresser and wardrobe.

November 6, 1964

We moved furniture out of dining room and Roberta waxed the floor. Then cleared the living room & put furniture in middle ready to varnish. Also I spoked at World Community Day at our church. It rained this afternoon.

November 7, 1964

Roberta varnished the living room, dining room, and the hall. All finished now. It cleared off and was warm. We have been very fortunate in the weather. We turned off the pilot light and had no fire all day because we thought it unsafe with the varnish.

November 8, 1964

Turned 2 pages. We moved everything out of the dining room and waxed the floor – then cleared living room [to] put furniture in the middle and got Taught my S.S. class & attended church. Mabel Bryson conducted my School of Missions class this evening. Showed pictures of Spanish American migrants in S.W. Oklahoma.

November 9, 1964

My dear friends Harold & Dorothy Leake came by briefly on their way to Calif. Ruth Leake was with them. They have just returned from a tour in their camper over England and the Continent. Roberta and I moved furniture back, hung pictures, etc. – all done but cleaning kitchen. It seems almost strange to be living in a real house once more Harold Edwards installed a new phone with extension cord.

November 10, 1964

Roberta cleaned the kitchen and tidied up some odds and ends that had been left. All done. And all shining clean! We have been very fortunate that the weather has been warm all the time.

November 11, 1964

I started in working on the program for the tour Saturday. Should have done it long ago but no chance. Our club met today – postponed from yesterday – but I did not attend. Couldn’t spare the time. Visited with Ramona and Pat this evening.

November 12, 1964

Worked all day on odds and ends for plans for the tour. The women who have had various responsibilities have done a wonderful job so that nothing was lost by my concentration on house work.

November 13, 1964

Nov. 14 Beautiful weather We had 13 visitors (from Thailand, Soudan [sic], India, Nicaragua) plus Dr. Curnow their advisor. Our tour was perfect everyone happy , good fellowship, enjoyable chuck wagon dinner at a roadside park. In the evening had supper with the Stanley Hitts – Dick Clark there, too – very happy evening.

November 14, 1964

Nov. 15 I taught my S.S. class then left immediately with Pat & Ramona O’Neill for Stillwater. Had dinner at Student Union with Marguerite Baumgartner. Fine visit – then I took the O’Neills through the Uni. library. Hard rain at Stillwater. Another rain hit Marshall this evening. I gave my School of Missions lesson to a very small group while it was pouring outside. My last lesson.

November 15, 1964

Nov. 16 It rained last night and most of the day. Not quite so warm as usual. A young student from OSU came to see me. His name is Melvin Fiegal and he is writing a history of Kingfisher for his master’s thesis in history. Nice boy.

November 16, 1964

[No entry]

November 17, 1964

It has never quit raining. Not really cold though snow has fallen in some parts of the U.S. northwest of us. They were glad to get it too for it has been very dry there.

November 18, 1964

Still raining all night, all day, and this evening. Not all the time but off and on. Oklahomans can’t stand being without the sun. This evening I went over to the O’Neill’s to see an hour’s program on TV in memory of President Kennedy. It showed him in incidents of his administration with excerpts from his speeches. Very fine.

November 19, 1964

Cleared off beautifully but getting cold.

November 20, 1964

White frost this morning – first one we have had. Pretty cold. I went to Enid to see Mrs. Hawkins. Her condition is pitiable – unable even to turn over and covered with bed sores. While I was there I got my Christmas letterheads.

November 21, 1964

I wrote several letters. Did a little cleaning of my house. A little dust had accumulated but it is still beautifully clean from the good going over it had by Roberta. Coldish day. Got a permanent.

November 22, 1964

Taught my S.S. class and attended church. Sermon better than usual. In the afternoon the Bosticks (Vernon, Roberta, Teresa, and Philip) came over and we played records of Kennedy’s speeches. We felt that was a proper observance of the day. They stayed all afternoon and we discussed politics in the very best sense of the word. Coldish day. In the evening I showed Plymouth pics at the church to the youth group – also in the morning to my S.S. class.

November 23, 1964

The Moses manuscript came from the two authors in Washington. Now I must go over it for final check. Those men have taken a wonderful attitude toward the suggestions I made. I wrote my Christmas letter and sent it to the printer. Nice day.

November 24, 1964

Worked in forenoon on Moses MS. The authors have done a brilliant job of rewriting. In P.M. attended Club at Winnie Branens. She gave the program, a fine one on Alaska with slides. In the evening Luella Reims called. Pleasant day but cool.

November 25, 1964

I worked some on the Moses MS. In the afternoon I drove to Stillwater and picked up a fine Finnish woman, Mrs. Nurmiaka and took her to spend Thanksgiving with the Reims. The Thanksgiving service was in our church this evening. Fine service. Three pastors participated. Nice day

November 26, 1964

The Schaefer girls and the Vernon Bosticks both invited me to Thanksgiving but I worked all day on the MS. The Bosticks (bless them) brought me a tray of turkey and everything. I had intended to eat a sandwich. Lovely weather.

November 27, 1964

I worked all day on the MS. It started clouding up this afternoon perhaps getting ready to storm. Glendora Hammer called briefly.

November 28, 1964

Lovely day. It didn’t storm. I worked on the MS. It is going to be a fine book. The authors did a fine job of revision after my work on it last summer.

November 29, 1964

Lovely morning. but the wind turned to the north about noon. I taught my S.S. class (August & Catherene there) but didn’t attend church. Had to hurry to eat and take Ruth Cromer to graveside service at the South Cemetery at one, for the burial of Mrs. Phil Reynolds. It was an ‘89er family and the children and I were in school together with Ruth as teacher. Few people remember them any more.

November 30, 1964

Cold bright day. August and Catherene Burchardt called briefly. I was so happy to see them. Attended S.S. teachers’ meeting at the church. Worked on the manuscript.

December 1, 1964

International hospitality met with me this morning. We made plans for foreign students for Christmas week. The rest of the time I worked on the MS.

December 2, 1964

Cloudy part of the day but not cold. I attended the Christmas covered dish luncheon and program of the guild. Enjoyable luncheon, fine program.

December 3, 1964

Freezing rain or freezing mist all day with a few flakes of snow. Dangerous to drive but more dangerous to walk so I drove. Not especially cold. I worked all day on the MS.

December 4, 1964

This morning the ice had evaporated from the pavement – no moisture to freeze on windshield – so driving to town was a relief. It cleared off in the afternoon. I worked all day on the MS. My Xmas letters came from the printer, but no time to send them out.

December 5, 1964

Nice bright day but crisp. I kept the library in the forenoon. The rest of the time I worked on the MS.

December 6, 1964

I taught my S.S. class and attended the preaching service. (Very good sermon.) In the p.m. Eldon Grassman and Oliver Rudd called on the Every Member Canvas. I enjoyed their visit very much. Bright day but crisp.

December 7, 1964

Worked this morning. Worked some on MS. Went to Enid in p.m. to see Mrs. Hawkins. Found her rapidly failing and very dissatisfied. Found traces of a big snow at Enid at the time we had our one-day of freezing rain and a few snowflakes here. Nice day today. Cold in morning but warmed up.

December 8, 1964

Worked on MS in morning. To see Went to Club at Mrs. Stuerkes in p.m. Fine program by Ramona, Ennmeier and Winnie Branen. In evening went to Voskuhls’ to talk about Mrs. Hawkins but they had company. I did see the baby – very fine boy, weighed 10 lbs. 5 oz. at birth. Nice day.

December 9, 1964

Worked at MS in morning. In p.m. made a pie. In evening went to church where my S.S. class & their children decorated the Xmas tree. Fine sociability. Pie and coffee served. Nice day. Some clouds but clear most of the time. Then at 11 p.m. surprised by a soft rain falling.

December 10, 1964

Ground all wet. It must have rained all night. Warm day with some rain. I worked all day on the MS. No chance to send Xmas letters.

December 11, 1964

[No entry]

December 12, 1964

Lovely day. Just more work on the MS. But it is going to be good. Wind changed to north about 4 – probably cold weather is on the way.

December 13, 1964

Taught my S.S. class, and attended church. The weather didn’t turn cold after all. Wrote letters in the afternoon, but haven’t started sending my Xmas letters.

December 14, 1964

Weather still nice. Worked on the MS. We got so few invitations for foreign students that we decided to call off our plans to have them here during vacation except possibly individual invitations.

December 15, 1964

Warm weather windy day. Worked on MS. In evening went to O’Neills’ to see “The Week That Was” on TV – then talked and listened to Xmas music.

December 16, 1964

Finished the MS except for some odds and ends that will wait until the authors can give some information. My S.S. class brought me a beautiful poinsetta [sic]. Nice day but turning cold this evening.

December 17, 1964

High wind blowing and very cold. I sent out letters. Cleaned half of my house. I shall not get a tree this year. I want the poinsetta [sic] to have the place the tree usually gets.

December 18, 1964

Still and bright and apparently not very cold but my car said it was, and I found thermometer got down to 3ᵒ. I sent out Christmas letters – worked some on odds and ends needing to be done on the MS.

December 19, 1964

Freezing rain fell in the night and the ground was covered with a glare of ice. I stayed in mildly afraid to drive, much more afraid to walk. Then the sun came out and in early afternoon the pavement was clear – even warm – in late afternoon. I went downtown for mail and groceries. Cleaned rest of my house.

December 20, 1964

Nice day. I taught my S.S. class and attended church. At 2:30 went to a “Jesus’ Birthday Party” given by the children at the Christian Church. Then went home with Ginger Hitt and spent a delightful evening with them. Ginger and I stepped across the street to a Christmas service at our church. Small congregation. Got beautiful plant from Dr. Ruby and Mr. Brown.

December 21, 1964

I am trying to send out Xmas letters but things keep coming up to add to the MS. The authors and I are keeping the mails hot. Cloudy this morning but cleared off.

December 22, 1964

Still dividing my time between the MS and Christmas letters. We are having lovely weather. I am enjoying my Xmas mail though it is piling up unanswered.

December 23, 1964

More of the same. So warm I turned off the furnace through the middle of the day.

December 24, 1964

Still letters & MS alternating. In the evening I attended the Xmas program at the church. Very fine. Lovely warm weather. Stanley Hitt brought some sweet rolls – Roberta and the children a cake. How nice.

December 25, 1964

Attended church (communion service) at 10:30. Ate dinner (not a Xmas dinner) with the O’Neills. Very pleasant. Worked on MS and finished answering my Xmas letters – haven’t initiated any yet on my own. Nice weather.

December 26, 1964

More work of same kind. Nice day.

December 27, 1964

Taught my S.S. class. Heard our pastor’s last sermon. I am worried about what is to become of that family. Ate dinner in the church basement with the Schaefer family – Leona and husband here. In evening Alden Grassman came and told me all about their problem with getting rid of minister & finding another. The church council has worked so conscientiously on this.

December 28, 1964

Same kind of work. Questions to authors, answers, changes on MS. It is going to be a very fine book.

December 29, 1964

The Schaefer sisters and Leona Schneebeck here this P.M. and I showed New England and other slides. Warm day.

December 30, 1964

I worked on one problem that has been bothering me on the MS – got some docs. I needed. I have only one left now, and that must wait till I get an answer to a letter I sent today. Nice warm day.

December 31, 1964

Cloudy all day, rain off and on, very foggy tonight. Still warm Received a calendar of lovely English scenes from the Millers.
